awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Secure and Efficient Solutions for Post-Quantum Cryptography for Codes with Compact Representations
awd_abstract_narration:
Current public-key cryptography is based on well-known problems from the area of mathematics called Number Theory. These problems are vulnerable to attacks able to exploit the superior computational power of Quantum computers (such as Shor's algorithm). Small Quantum computers are already a reality, and the cryptographic community is currently hard at work to design the new cryptographic standards which will become actual once sufficiently large Quantum computers finally become available, making current cryptographic solutions obsolete. Code-based cryptography is one of the most accredited candidates to provide secure cryptographic primitives in the Post-Quantum era. In this project, we seek  to create efficient and long-term secure cryptographic primitives from code-based cryptography. The project's novelties are the investigation, development, and deployment of techniques to obtain code-based cryptosystems featuring efficient performance and small public keys. The project's impacts are a substantial contribution to the standardization effort led by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), as well as a boost of the US and Israeli footprint in the area of post-quantum cryptography.

The team of researchers, composed of a US investigator and an Israeli counterpart, proposes to employ a recent approach based on so-called Reproducible Codes to shorten the key size of cryptosystems based on codes defined by a sparse parity-check matrix. These include two of the current candidates to NIST's standardization effort, both of which have been admitted to the second round of the competition. Furthermore, the investigators seek to incorporate techniques to reduce the decoding-failure rate of such cryptosystems, in order to design schemes that allow the usage of static, long-term keys. Finally, the team plans to produce efficient and secure implementations for all the primitives investigated, which will safeguard against side-channel attacks and other physical and engineering attacks

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
It is well-known that, once quantum computers of an appropriate size are available, current cryptographic solutions, based on traditional number theory problems, will become insecure, and therefore obsolete. This means that nearly every practical application of cryptography in use today will be compromised, making e-commerce and many other digital applications that we rely on in our daily lives (such as the TLS or SSH protocols for the internet) completely insecure. It is in this spirit that the National Institute for Standards and Technology, in 2017, launched a worldwide call for proposals, to define, implement and evaluate new "post-quantum" cryptographic standards, with the goal of replacing the current ones.

Code-based cryptography is one of the most accredited candidates to provide secure cryptographic primitives in the post-quantum era. The area, which devises cryptosystems using tools specifically from coding theory, has been around as long as public-key cryptography itself, and has been extensively studied, so that it offers robust security guarantees. At the same time, the wide-scale deployment of code-based systems has historically been hindered by some technical drawback, such as the very large size of its public keys.

In this project, we strived to address this issue by creating efficient and long-term secure cryptographic primitives from code-based cryptography, in the context of encryption and key establishment. In practice, this meant proposing several improvements to the original work by McEliece, known as the McEliece cryptosystem (1978), to make it viable for modern requirements. We investigated a recent approach based on "reproducible" codes, i.e. codes which can be represented in a very compact way; among these, the most popular are undoubtedly Quasi-Cyclic (QC) codes. Combined with a code family exhibiting good decoding and structural properties, known as Moderate-Density Parity-Check (MDPC) codes, this yields the cryptographic suite called "BIKE", acronym for BIt-flipping Key Encapsulation. BIKE, who is now one of the 3 final candidates in NIST's effort, sees both PIs among its submitters, and represents one of the most credible candidates for post-quantum standards.

Our contributions to BIKE's success, as part of this project, are multiple and of considerable importance. First, at a theoretical level, we were able to rigorously prove that it is possible, for BIKE, to satisfy the highest level of security for encryption (known as IND-CCA), if certain design conditions are satisfied. Among other things, this enables BIKE to be used in specific scenarios such as long-term key exchanges. Secondly, we devised efficient, optimized implementations for BIKE, both at the algorithmic level (e.g. devising a new, high-performance algorithm for polynomial inversion) and at the software level (exploiting advanced tools such as AVX instructions).

Our project was relevant in terms of broader impacts, too. First of all, it contributed greatly to increasing the footprint of both U.S. and Israeli institutions inside NIST's call, which was otherwise extremely limited. Secondly, a seminar series was established, named "Crypto Cafe", hosted at FAU and entirely recorded. Finally, the grant contributed to the development and deployment of a Cybersecurity summer camp, part of a larger initiative under the name of Young CryptograpHers, to raise awareness and participation in the area among minorities - in this case, K-12 female students.
